meta.title: Dermatology E&D - Mission NEET PG 2.0 - Final Batch - 11-06-2025 - 2025-06-11

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with joint stiffness, fatigue, low-grade fever, and a photosensitive facial rash. She reports generalized body aches and difficulty performing daily tasks due to pain and stiffness in her hands and knees. Routine blood work reveals mild anemia. Urinalysis is unremarkable. A provisional diagnosis of SLE was made. Based on prevalence rates of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) manifestations during the disease course, which of the following is the most likely presenting cutaneous feature in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Photosensitivity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Photosensitivity is the most common cutaneous manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus, occurring in approximately 70% of patients over the course of the disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a lean build presents with newly developed, extensive hyperpigmented, velvety plaques over his axillae and neck. On physical examination, he also has rugose thickening of the palmar skin resembling "tripe palms." These findings developed rapidly over the past few weeks. Which of the following underlying conditions is most likely associated with his presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gastric cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of sudden-onset, extensive acanthosis nigricans and tripe palms in a non-obese adult is strongly associated with underlying gastric adenocarcinoma as part of a paraneoplastic syndrome.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman in her second trimester presents with severe nocturnal pruritus and excoriated papules in the finger webs, wrists, and waistline. The diagnosis of scabies is made clinically. Which of the following therapeutic agent is considered appropriate and safe for the management of scabies during pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Permethrin 5% cream

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Permethrin 5% cream is the first-line treatment for scabies during pregnancy due to its excellent efficacy and established safety profile.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true about thalidomide? Its immunosuppressive action is due to antimetabolite effects Used in management of refractory relapsing multiple myeloma Used in management of Type 1 Lepra reaction It is a teratogenic drug to foetus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thalidomide is FDA-approved for erythema nodosum leprosum and multiple myeloma. It works via immunomodulatory, anti-TNF-α, anti-angiogenic, and cereblon-mediated pathways, and is highly teratogenic during pregnancy.

questions.text: Which options are correct among the following? Epidermis can regenerate from deeper follicular cells such as hair follicles and apocrine glands Stratum corneum is the outermost acellular layer Epidermis is ectodermal in origin Dermis and hypodermis are endodermal in origin
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The stratum corneum is the acellular outermost layer of the epidermis, which is ectodermal in origin, while the dermis and hypodermis arise from mesoderm. Apocrine glands do not contribute to epidermal stem cell regeneration.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with a solitary painless ulcer in the genital region that developed 10 days ago. Over the past 3 days, she has developed tender, swollen inguinal lymph nodes, some of which appear fluctuant. She has no prior history of similar lesions. Based on this clinical course, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) LGV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is characterized by a transient painless genital ulcer followed by painful, often suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo formation), distinguishing it from other sexually transmitted infections.

questions.text: A male patient presents with complaints of progressive hair loss over the scalp. On examination, there is diffuse thinning involving the crown and frontal scalp, but the frontal hairline is preserved. Based on this pattern, which of the following is the most likely type of hair loss?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Female pattern baldness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Female pattern baldness can present in males and is characterized by diffuse thinning over the crown and frontal scalp with preservation of the frontal hairline.

questions.text: Identify the false statement among the following:

options.label: A
options.text: Spongiosis is seen in Acute Eczema

options.label: B
options.text: Spongiosis is the thickening of Stratum Spinosum

options.label: C
options.text: Acantholysis is seen in Pemphigus vulgaris

questions.correct_answer: B. Spongiosis is the thickening of Stratum Spinosum
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Spongiosis is the thickening of Stratum Spinosum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spongiosis is intercellular edema of the stratum spinosum seen in acute eczema; it is not the same as thickening (which is called acanthosis).

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with a history of allergic contact dermatitis undergoes a patch test as part of his diagnostic workup. After applying the patches to his back, when should he be scheduled to return for removal of the patches?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 48 hours

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patch tests used for diagnosing allergic contact dermatitis should be removed at 48 hours to allow detection of Type IV hypersensitivity responses; additional readings may be done at 96 hours to identify late reactions.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the clinic due to an mildly itchy skin lesion over his lower leg that has gradually enlarged over several weeks. He reports that the area began as a red patch and has expanded outward without central fading. On physical examination, there is a large, salmon-colored plaque with clearly demarcated margins and covered by silvery-white scales on the anterior shin. Based on clinical morphology, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Psoriasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Psoriasis presents as well-demarcated, salmon-colored plaques with silvery-white scales and no central clearing. In contrast, Tinea corporis features annular plaques with central clearing and an advancing erythematous scaly margin. Recognizing these morphologic differences is essential for accurate diagnosis.
  • ➤ Tinea corporis

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl was brought to the clinic with multiple small pigmented macules over her face that became more prominent following a recent beach trip to Hawaii. Her family notes that these lesions become darker with sun exposure and fade in the winter. Her father also has similar facial lesions. Regarding the pathophysiology and features of this condition, which of the following statements is false?

options.label: A
options.text: It is associated with xeroderma pigmentosa

options.label: B
options.text: It is caused by increased melanin

options.label: C
options.text: Increased number of melanocytes are seen

options.label: D
options.text: It has an autosomal dominant inheritance

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased number of melanocytes are seen
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increased number of melanocytes are seen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Freckles (ephelides) show increased melanin production without an increase in melanocyte number. This distinguishes them histologically from lentigines and other pigmented lesions. Recognizing this key point helps avoid common diagnostic errors.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to urgent care with complaints of an intensely pruritic skin lesion on his torso that began three days ago. The lesion is erythematous, mildly scaly, and has a slightly raised border. He denies systemic symptoms and reports that the itching worsens with sweating. There is no history of similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tinea corporis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tinea corporis presents as an intensely pruritic, annular lesion with raised scaly borders and central clearing, typically appearing over a few days. It is a superficial dermatophyte infection and must be distinguished from other non-pruritic, slowly evolving dermatoses like granuloma annulare or ichthyosis vulgaris.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with generalized redness, scaling, and thickening of the skin that started on the trunk and gradually spread to involve most of the body surface. There is associated mild itching and warmth over the skin, but no systemic symptoms. On examination, diffuse erythema with fine scaling and patches of exfoliation is noted across the back. Based on the available data, which of the following is the most common cause of this dermatologic condition in adults?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Eczema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eczema is the most common cause of erythroderma in adults, accounting for 40% of cases. Always consider eczema first in diffuse scaling erythema unless systemic features or drug history suggests an alternative.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with sharply demarcated depigmented macules on her face and hands. These lesions have gradually spread over time, and she has no associated pain or itching. There is no history of trauma, but she reports a family history of autoimmune conditions. Considering the diagnosis and its common associations, which of the following autoimmune diseases is most strongly linked to this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thyroid disorders

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Among autoimmune conditions associated with vitiligo, thyroid disorders (both hypo- and hyperthyroidism) show the strongest and most consistent association. Other less common associations include Addison's disease, type 1 diabetes mellitus, and pernicious anemia.

questions.text: Which of the following methods are used as criteria for the diagnosis of leprosy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Both A and B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leprosy diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical findings and bacteriological evidence (slit skin smear). Neither method alone is sufficient; both are required for accurate diagnosis and classification into paucibacillary or multibacillary forms.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man who works in agriculture presents with a gradually enlarging, painless swelling over the dorsal aspect of his left foot. The lesion has developed multiple draining sinuses that intermittently discharge pale-colored granules. There is no fever or systemic complaint, but he reports working barefoot in fields for many years. Based on the clinical appearance, occupational exposure, and nature of granules, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Actinomycetoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Actinomycetoma is a type of mycetoma caused by bacteria (e.g., Actinomadura madurae, Nocardia brasiliensis) and is characterized by pale granules in sinus discharge. It must be distinguished from eumycetoma, which is caused by fungi (e.g., Madurella mycetomatis) and shows black granules. Accurate diagnosis influences treatment strategy—antibiotics for actinomycetoma and antifungals for eumycetoma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with scaly, erythematous plaques over her face and ear. The lesions have been persistent for several months, showing gradual progression with scarring and pigmentary changes. On examination, there is a well-demarcated plaque with central atrophy and adherent scales involving the concha and external ear canal. This ear involvement pattern is known as the “Shuster’s sign.” Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE) commonly involves sun-exposed areas and is characterized by scarring plaques with central atrophy and peripheral hyperpigmentation. Involvement of the conchal bowl and external auditory canal—Shuster’s sign—is a classic hallmark of DLE, not seen in other dermatoses.

questions.text: Which of the following are characteristic features of leprosy (Hansen’s disease)? Itching along the lesion Painful trophic ulcers Glove and stocking hypoesthesia Purple, polygonal, papules and plaques
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Only 3 is correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The glove and stocking pattern of sensory loss is a characteristic feature of leprosy, due to the involvement of long peripheral nerves. In contrast, itching, painful ulcers, and purple polygonal plaques are not features of leprosy and help in differentiating it from other dermatoses like lichen planus or neuropathic ulcers of other etiologies.

questions.text: A parent brings their child to the clinic noting a white patch of hair (poliosis) on the frontal scalp and a depigmented patch on the central forehead, both present since birth. Physical examination confirms a well-demarcated area of skin and hair depigmentation, with no scaling or inflammation. What is the most likely mechanism underlying this cutaneous finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Impaired migration of melanocytes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Piebaldism is a congenital condition characterized by stable, localized depigmented patches of skin and hair (poliosis), resulting from impaired migration of melanocytes due to a c-KIT gene mutation. It presents at birth and should be differentiated from progressive or systemic causes of hypopigmentation.

questions.text: A full-term male newborn is presented at the neonatal care unit with membranes covering the entire body, separated by deep erythematous fissures. The baby exhibits ectropion, eclabium. Based on these findings, which of the following conditions is least likely to be the correct diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ichthyosis vulgaris

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ichthyosis vulgaris presents with fine scaling in early childhood and does not involve a collodion membrane or severe features like ectropion and eclabium, making it least likely in a newborn with congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma. Harlequin and lamellar ichthyosis often present at birth with membrane-like skin involvement.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with diffuse reddish-orange discoloration of the trunk and upper limbs, accompanied by areas of follicular hyperkeratosis and rough, scaly skin as seen in the image. On histopathological evaluation, there is a combination of orthokeratosis and parakeratosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pityriasis rubra pilaris (PRP)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pityriasis rubra pilaris (PRP) presents with orange-red scaly plaques, follicular hyperkeratosis, and characteristic histology of alternating orthokeratosis and parakeratosis, making it distinct from other papulosquamous disorders.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child is brought to the outpatient clinic with grey, scaly patches over the scalp associated with partial hair loss. The lesions are circular and show green fluorescence under Wood's lamp examination. There is no evidence of inflammation, boggy swelling, or pustule formation. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ectothrix

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Grey patch tinea capitis is caused by ectothrix fungal infection with arthrospores on the outside of the hair shaft, commonly due to Microsporum species. It presents with scaly, circular grey patches of alopecia that show green fluorescence under Wood's lamp, aiding in diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a common side effect of isotretinoin therapy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hepatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatitis is not a common side effect of isotretinoin; it is rarely reported, with only occasional cases of toxic hepatitis or pancreatitis from hypertriglyceridemia. In contrast, cheilitis, myalgia, and arthralgia are well-established and common adverse effects of this retinoid.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man presents with fever and painful, nodular skin lesions with mucopurulent discharge on his lower leg, evolving over the past 10 days. A Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain performed on the discharge is negative. Based on this clinical presentation and stain result, which organism is most likely to be isolated on culture?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Botryomycosis is a bacterial infection that mimics mycotic infections and is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It presents with painful, discharging nodules or masses and is characterized by negative fungal stains (e.g., GMS). A short history and acute purulent features help distinguish it from chronic infections like actinomycetoma or deep fungal diseases.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with mucoid urethral discharge that began approximately 2 weeks after unprotected sexual contact. There are no systemic symptoms, but the discharge is persistent. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test for identifying the likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) are the first-line diagnostic tests for suspected urethritis, especially when caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Chlamydia trachomatis. They are highly sensitive, specific, and non-invasive, making them superior to older methods like culture or microscopy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with multiple flaccid blisters and erosions involving the oral mucosa and upper torso. The lesions rupture easily, and Nikolsky’s sign is positive. Clinical suspicion of pemphigus vulgaris is high. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line investigation to support the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tzanck smear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In suspected pemphigus vulgaris, a Tzanck smear is the first-line bedside investigation for rapid identification of acantholytic cells, aiding in early diagnosis. Definitive confirmation is done by direct immunofluorescence (DIF) and desmoglein antibody assays.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a single hypopigmented skin lesion and a nearby satellite lesion. On clinical examination, no peripheral nerve thickening is noted. According to the revised WHO/NLEP guidelines (effective April 1, 2025), which of the following is the most appropriate treatment regimen for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Packet 2 for 6 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Under the 2025 revised WHO/NLEP guidelines, Packet 2 (rifampicin + clofazimine + dapsone) is the standard treatment for both PB and MB leprosy, replacing older 2-drug regimens. Duration is 6 months for PB and 12 months for MB. Proper classification depends on number of skin lesions, nerve involvement, and Slit Skin smear status.

questions.text: A school-aged girl being treated for seizure disorder with valproic acid presents with scaly dermatitis, patchy hair loss, and intermittent constrictions of hair shafts (trichorrhexis nodosa-like pattern). She reports being bullied due to her hair changes. On local examination, there is scalp scaling and hair fragility. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vitamin H (Biotin)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Biotin (Vitamin H) deficiency can result in scaly dermatitis, alopecia, and hair shaft abnormalities such as intermittent constrictions. Long-term valproic acid use is a recognized cause of biotin deficiency, especially in children.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with a painless, indurated ulcer that developed 3 weeks ago and has not responded to oral antibiotics. On examination, there is non-tender left axillary lymphadenopathy. The lesion is clean-based and not purulent. Further history reveals a recent episode of digital penetration during sexual activity. Based on the clinical features and exposure history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chancre

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Chancre, the hallmark of primary syphilis, is a painless, indurated ulcer often associated with non-tender lymphadenopathy. It may occur at extragenital sites depending on the route of transmission, such as digital sexual contact. Failure to respond to routine antibiotics and classic features should prompt consideration of syphilis.

questions.text: A child with a background of chronic atopic dermatitis presents with sudden onset of high-grade fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, and numerous vesicular lesions scattered over the face and body. The vesicles are located on an erythematous base, and some are beginning to crust. The child’s condition worsened rapidly following close contact with an infected relative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Kaposi varicelliform eruption

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kaposi varicelliform eruption (eczema herpeticum) is a viral superinfection (typically HSV) in patients with atopic dermatitis, characterized by high fever, lymphadenopathy, and widespread vesicular eruptions on eczematous skin. It is a dermatologic emergency requiring prompt antiviral therapy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought in due to persistent intense scalp itching. The symptoms began shortly after she changed schools. On close inspection of her hair, several firmly adherent oval white structures are noted along the hair shafts, which can be slid but not easily removed. There is no visible erythema, scaling, or hair loss. What is the most appropriate approved treatment for this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Permethrin 1% lotion application, repeated after 7 days

options.label: D
options.text: Permethrin 5% lotion application, repeated after 7 days

questions.correct_answer: B. Permethrin 1% lotion application, repeated after 7 days
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Permethrin 1% lotion application, repeated after 7 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pediculosis capitis (head lice) presents with scalp itching and firmly adherent nits on hair shafts. The first-line treatment is permethrin 1% lotion, applied and repeated after 7 days, as it is not ovicidal. Correct diagnosis and simultaneous treatment of close contacts prevent reinfestation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman reports persistent redness of her cheeks, nose, forehead, and chin for several months. She also notes the presence of pimples and pustules, but denies any oily skin or comedones. She is embarrassed by frequent flushing episodes, especially after spicy food or hot beverages. On examination, you note erythema, telangiectasia, and dome-shaped papulopustules over the central face. The periorbital and perioral areas are spared. What is the most appropriate topical treatment for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Topical metronidazole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Papulopustular rosacea is a chronic skin condition characterized by central facial erythema, telangiectasia, and dome-shaped papules/pustules without comedones. It is commonly seen in middle-aged women and is aggravated by environmental and dietary triggers. The first-line topical treatment is metronidazole, which targets inflammation and helps clear lesions. Avoidance of topical steroids is crucial to prevent worsening.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought for evaluation of swelling of the feet and general irritability. On physical examination, you observe pitting peripheral edema, abdominal distension, and bands of alternating hypopigmented and normal pigmented hair. The child also has sparse, brittle hair and a dull facial expression. Which of the following nutritional deficiencies is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Kwashiorkor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The flag sign—alternating hypopigmented and pigmented bands of hair—is a hallmark feature of Kwashiorkor, reflecting nutritional fluctuation during growth spurts. It occurs in conjunction with peripheral edema, hepatomegaly, skin changes, and brittle hair in protein-deficient malnutrition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a known history of herpes zoster affecting the left thoracic dermatome 3 months ago now presents with new-onset granuloma annulare–like plaques precisely over the same previously affected dermatome. The lesions are confined to the area previously involved and are unrelated to trauma or infection spread. What is the term used to describe the development of a new skin disorder at the site of a previously healed dermatologic lesion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Isotopic phenomenon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The isotopic phenomenon describes the appearance of a new, unrelated skin disorder at the site of a previously healed lesion, commonly following herpes zoster. This is distinct from isomorphic (Koebner), pseudo-Koebner, and reverse Koebner phenomena, which involve same disease, infectious spread, and lesion disappearance, respectively.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the clinic with crusting skin lesions around the mouth that started as small red spots and rapidly progressed. The mother reports the lesions began after mild trauma to the skin. On examination, there are golden-yellow crusted erosions around the perioral area, but no intraoral involvement or systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Impetigo

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Non-bullous impetigo is a common, highly contagious superficial bacterial skin infection in children, presenting with honey-colored crusts on the face, particularly around the nose and mouth. Prompt recognition and treatment are essential to prevent spread and complications.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is admitted for evaluation of non-scaly red lesions over his lower legs. On examination, the lesions are non-blanching, erythematous, and distributed symmetrically. You are consulted to determine whether the erythema is due to intravascular dilation or extravasation of blood. Which of the following bedside clinical tests would best help differentiate between these causes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Diascopy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diascopy is a valuable bedside test used to differentiate between blanchable erythema (due to vasodilation) and non-blanchable purpura (due to blood extravasation), especially in patients with non-scaly red rashes such as in vasculitis or purpuric dermatoses.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman asks about the factors influencing her skin color while being evaluated for uneven pigmentation. Which of the following statements regarding skin pigmentation is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: Eumelanin contributes to brown and black pigmentation

options.label: B
options.text: The number of melanocytes determines human skin color

options.label: C
options.text: Pheomelanin is responsible for yellow-red pigmentation

options.label: D
options.text: The epidermal melanin unit consists of approximately 36 keratinocytes per melanocyte

questions.correct_answer: B. The number of melanocytes determines human skin color
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The number of melanocytes determines human skin color

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Skin color in humans is determined primarily by the amount, type, and distribution of melanin—not the number of melanocytes. The epidermal melanin unit and the melanin transfer process play central roles in pigmentation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with multiple flaccid blisters and erosions on his trunk and oral mucosa. The blisters are painful and rupture easily, leaving raw areas. Nikolsky sign is positive. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Systemic corticosteroids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Systemic corticosteroids are the treatment of choice for pemphigus vulgaris, a severe autoimmune blistering disease. Prompt initiation is critical to reduce mortality. Steroid-sparing agents like rituximab are reserved for refractory or steroid-dependent cases.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to present with annular skin lesions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Urticaria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Urticaria typically presents with wheals, not annular lesions. In contrast, tinea corporis, porokeratosis, and pityriasis rosea are all well-known to manifest with annular skin lesions. Understanding lesion morphology helps in narrowing dermatologic differentials.

questions.text: A skin biopsy from a patient with eczematous lesions is evaluated under the microscope. The histopathological image reveals spongiosis. What is the most accurate interpretation of this finding?
questions.correct_answer: B. Intercellular edema in stratum spinosum
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Intercellular edema in stratum spinosum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spongiosis, or intercellular edema in the stratum spinosum, is a key histologic feature of eczematous dermatitis and leads to vesicle formation and epidermal separation. Recognizing this feature is essential in diagnosing various acute and chronic inflammatory dermatoses.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents with urethral discharge and dysuria that started 5 days after engaging in unprotected sexual intercourse. He noticed the discharge the following morning and promptly sought care. Gram stain of the urethral swab shows Gram-negative intracellular diplococci. What is the most appropriate treatment regimen for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Inj. Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM single dose + Tab. Azithromycin 1 g PO single dose

options.label: B
options.text: Oral Amoxicillin 1 g three times a day for 5 days

options.label: C
options.text: Inj. Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM single dose

options.label: D
options.text: Any of the above are acceptable regimens

questions.correct_answer: A. Inj. Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM single dose + Tab. Azithromycin 1 g PO single dose
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inj. Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM single dose + Tab. Azithromycin 1 g PO single dose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Empiric treatment of gonococcal urethritis should include dual therapy with ceftriaxone and azithromycin to cover both N. gonorrhoeae and potential co-infection with Chlamydia trachomatis, even if only one pathogen is identified. This approach minimizes missed co-infections and helps curb antimicrobial resistance.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman who works as a washerwoman presents with whitish maceration between the toes, particularly in the web spaces. On examination, moist, whitish lesions with surrounding erythema and multiple small satellite pustules are noted. There is no nail involvement, and the symptoms began after prolonged wet work. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Candidiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Candidiasis involving web spaces presents as whitish moist maceration with satellite pustules, especially in individuals with prolonged moisture exposure such as washerwomen. This distinguishes it from tinea pedis, eczema, and psoriasis, which lack satellite lesions and typically have drier presentations.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female presents for follow-up regarding her acne which predominantly presented as pustular lesions, which has persisted despite treatment for the past 6 months. She reports minimal improvement with her current regimen, which included oral antibiotics and topical agents. There is no history of recent medication change or steroid use. What is the most appropriate next step in her treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Oral retinoids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with moderate to severe acne who show poor response to standard treatment after several months, oral isotretinoin is the drug of choice. It is the most effective agent for recalcitrant, pustular, or nodulocystic acne, and should be initiated after evaluating for potential contraindications.

questions.text: Based on this smear finding, which of the following conditions is least likely to show similar cytological changes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pox virus infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acantholytic cells seen on Tzanck smear are characteristic of intraepidermal blistering diseases like pemphigus vulgaris and Darier’s disease. These cells are not seen in poxvirus infections, which show viral cytopathic effects, not acantholysis. Thus, poxvirus is the least likely cause of the smear findings shown.

questions.text: A child is brought to the outpatient clinic with multiple tense bullae over the torso and extremities. A skin biopsy reveals subepidermal blister formation with predominant neutrophilic infiltration. Direct immunofluorescence shows a linear band of IgA at the dermoepidermal junction. What is the most appropriate drug of choice in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dapsone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic Bullous Disease of Childhood (CBDC) is a linear IgA-mediated subepidermal blistering disorder, most common in children under 5 years. The treatment of choice is Dapsone, which suppresses neutrophil-driven blister formation, and leads to rapid clinical improvement.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with asymptomatic blue pigmented lesions on his face since birth. Upon examination, bluish pigmentation is also noted in the sclera. He reports no changes in the lesions over time. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nevus of Ota

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nevus of Ota is characterized by bluish-gray pigmentation on the face and can also involve the sclera. It is a congenital condition involving dermal melanocytes typically affecting the ophthalmic and maxillary regions of the face.

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer presents with a single warty lesion on his leg that has persisted for several months. Given his occupation and the appearance of the lesion, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis caused by inoculation of the bacteria into the skin. It presents as a warty lesion, particularly in individuals with a history of exposure, such as farmers. Proper identification and treatment are essential to prevent chronicity and complications.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic woman presents with acute onset of pain, redness, and swelling in her lower leg. The rash has spread rapidly over a day and is associated with warmth and tenderness. On examination, the lesion appears sharply demarcated, raised, and intensely erythematous. Her history is notable for chronic venous insufficiency and diabetes mellitus. Based on the clinical features and appearance, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Erysipelas

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erysipelas presents as a well-demarcated, raised, and erythematous skin lesion with rapid progression and tenderness, often in patients with diabetes or venous insufficiency. It is distinct from cellulitis, which has ill-defined borders and involves deeper tissues.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the clinic due to the development of red, raised spots predominantly on the lower extremities and buttocks. The parent reports that the child also experiences intermittent abdominal pain and swelling in the knees and ankles. Laboratory investigations are notable for normal platelet count and kidney function. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glucocorticoids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP) is a small vessel vasculitis seen predominantly in children, presenting with palpable purpura, joint pain, abdominal pain, and renal involvement. Glucocorticoids are the treatment of choice for severe symptoms such as abdominal pain or renal disease.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with diffuse erythroderma, severe pruritus, and generalized lymphadenopathy. A skin biopsy reveals the presence of atypical T lymphocytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mycosis fungoides

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mycosis fungoides is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma characterized by atypical T lymphocytes with cerebriform nuclei infiltrating the skin. It can present with patchy, plaque-like lesions or erythroderma in advanced stages. Skin biopsy findings of atypical lymphocytes and diffuse erythroderma are key diagnostic features.
